children.value: We choose a function over the interval

children.html: [0,1][0,1][0,1]
fff

children.value: and its polynomial interpolant using seven equally spaced nodes.

plot(f, 0, 1, label="function", legend=:bottomleft)
t = range(0, 1, 7)    # 7 equally spaced nodes
y = f.(t)
scatter!(t, y, label="nodes")

p = FNC.polyinterp(t, y)
plot!(p, 0, 1, label="interpolant", title="Equispaced interpolant, n=6")
This looks pretty good. We want to track the behavior of the error as

children.html: nnn

children.value: increases. We will estimate the error in the continuous interpolant by sampling it at a large number of points and taking the max-norm.

n = 5:5:60
err = zeros(size(n))
x = range(0, 1, 2001)             # for measuring error
for (k, n) in enumerate(n)
    t = range(0, 1, n+1)          # equally spaced nodes
    y = f.(t)                     # interpolation data
    p = FNC.polyinterp(t, y)
    err[k] = norm((@. f(x) - p(x)), Inf)
end
plot(n, err, m=:o, 
    xaxis=(L"n"), yaxis=(:log10, "max error"),
    title="Interpolation error for equispaced nodes")
The error initially decreases as one would expect but then begins to grow. Both phases occur at rates that are exponential in

children.html: nnn
O(KnO(K^nO(Kn
KKK

children.value: , appearing linear on a semi-log plot.
